content.statement: The Discount Factor is the multiplier used to convert a future cash flow to its present value, calculated as DF = 1 / (1 + r)^t
content.intuition: The discount factor shrinks future cash flows to present value. Higher discount rates or longer time periods = smaller discount factors = less valuable future cash flows.
key_insights: Discount factor is always between 0 and 1 for positive discount rates
Higher risk → higher r → lower DF → lower present value
DF at t=0 is always 1.0 (no discounting for immediate cash)
Discount factor is the reciprocal of compound growth factor

r.description: Discount rate per period (as decimal, e.g., 0.10 for 10%)
r.constraints: typically 0 < r < 1, can be negative in rare cases

t.description: Number of time periods into the future

examples.interpretation: $1 received in 5 years is worth $0.62 today at 10% discount rate

examples.description: Compare discount factors at different rates
examples.interpretation: Higher discount rates dramatically reduce value of distant cash flows

learning_objectives: Calculate discount factors for any rate and period
Understand inverse relationship with compound interest
Apply discount factors to find present values
Interpret economic meaning of discount factors
common_errors: Forgetting to raise to power of t
Using percentage instead of decimal (use 0.10 not 10)
Confusing discount factor with discount rate
practice_problems: Calculate discount factor for year 7 at 8% rate
If DF_3 = 0.75, what is the discount rate?
